SECRET
GOVERNMENT OF INDIA

BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
A- WING, JANPATH BHAWAN ,
JANPATH, NEW DELHI-110001
CAS-12/CP/COE/2011
Dated: 2.2.2011
AVSEC ORDER No. 1'/2011
Subject:
- Contingency
Plan for handling aircraft hijack situation-2011
In the exercise of powers conferred by Section 5A of Aircraft Act, 1934,
delegated to him vide Government of India, Ministry of Civil Aviation Notification
No 1797 dated 03rd July 1997, for the purpose of securing the aircraft operations
and access control at the civil airports in India, the Commissioner of Security
(CA) directs that the enclosed Contingency Plan for handling aircraft hijack
situation, which has been updated to comply with the requirements of Standards
of Annex-17
to
the
Convention
on
International Civil Aviation,
shall
be
implemented by all agencies connected with aviation security in India.
2.
This
is
in
continuation
of
guidelines
issued
by
MCA vide
Office
Memorandum No AV.133024/2/2000-SS
dated 13 September 2005.
3.
Any violation of this AVSEC Order shall attract penalty under Section 11A
of the Aircraft Act, 1934.
~
(Gurjo~
Commissioner of Security (CA)
Distribution
:
As per list attached.

SECRET

Government
of India
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter I
INTRODUCTION
1.1
The ContingencyPlan for dealing with unlawful interference to civil
aviation
alms
at
ensuring
adequate
advance
preparedness
and
instantaneous response to effectivelycounter such unlawful interference.
The plan seeks to set up a structure capable of switching to hands-on
mode with necessary action within moments of receipt of information
about such unlawful interference.
1.2.
Unlawful interference to civil aviation may be broadly defined III
twocategories:-
(a)
Unlawful act of seizure of aircraft on ground or while Ill-
flight.
(b)
Unlawful acts relating to airport, for example: armed attack
within the airport boundaries; armed attack on aircraft or
installations from external points near the airport perimeter;
unlawful act of seizure of installations vital to the operation
of civilaviation; and sabotage ofaircraft or vital installations.
1.3
This Contingency Plan deals with unlawful acts of seizure of
aircraft i.e hijacking. The incidents of unlawful acts relating to the
airport should be dealt with within the structure of handling of internal
security incidents of similar nature by the State Government through an
integrated response system, which incorporates the first reaction role of
QRT(QuickReaction Teams)at the airports also,
since these situations
2
SECRET
5:
SECRET
•
Government of India
.
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter I
INTRODUCTION
are similar to situations
of such unlawful acts against any vital
installation, public utility etc. The guidance/support of Ministryof Home
Affairs , may be
obtained
by the
State
Government
as
per
requirement of the situation.
1.4
Followinglikely scenarios are envisaged in regard to unlawful acts
of seizure of an aircraft:-
(a)
Indian registered aircraft after hijacking lands at an Indian
airport.
(b)
Indian registered aircraft after hijacking
IS being taken
outside the country
(c)
Indian registered aircraft after hijacking lands at a foreign
airport.
(d)
A foreign registered aircraft after hijacking lands at an
Indian airport.
(e)
An aircraft is hijacked for being used as a missile to attack
strategic targets.
1.5
The Contingency Plan has been formulated keeping the following
principles in view:-
(a)
A clearly defined policy and decision making system with
Cabinet Committeeon Security (CCS)at the apex.
3

Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter I
INTRODUCTION
(b)
Clear definitionof the roles of different Governmentagencies
with their own sub-plans for effectivelydischarging their
role/ responsibilities.
(c)
An institutionalized system for instantaneous
hands on
response
at
the
airport level, suitably supported with
requisite arms, equipment, forcesand training.
(d)
A well designed system for flow of information and
communication both internally for decision making and
externally for the media and friends/relatives of the affected
passengers/ functionaries.
(e)
In case of an aircraft hijacked for being used as a missile the
situation
should
be handled
as
per
the
Coordination
Procedures and Standing Operating Procedures.
1.6.
Doctrine:- Basic doctrines on which a directive for hijacking may
be established are:
I
An attempt to hijack an aircraft will be considered to be a
terrorist
act against the country and
shall provoke a
response as against an aggressor.
11
There shall be no negotiation on the demands of hijackers.
Negotiation,if any, shall only be tactical.
111
If an Indian registered aircraft is hijacked, personnel at all
airports shall, without seeking any order from a superior
authority, see to immobilizethe aircraft at that airport itself.
IV
In case an aircraft is hijacked and is airborne, the IAFfighter
planes shall escort it within Indian airspace at all times.
4

7:
SECRET
~
Government of India
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
,
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter I
INTRODUCTION
v
Once it is determined that a hijacked aircraft is to be used as
a missile to hit strategic targets or thickly populated
buildings/ areas, due to chances of collateral damage, the
decision to term aircraft as "threat' is to be taken on case to
case basis. Also, such buildings/areas need to be identified
& earmarked so that list of such vital targets should be
available with radar units and at decision making centres,
and action taken by the IAF as per CoordinationProcedures
and SOP.
VI
Penalty for hijacking shall be death penalty.
1.7
Followingshall be the policyofGovernmentof India in dealingwith
acts ofunlawful seizure ofaircraft: -
(a)Allefforts should be made to get any hijacked Indian registered
aircraft to land at an Indian Airport preferably one of those
already identified for this purpose. Once such an aircraft lands
at an Indian airport it shall be immediately immobilizedand
shall not be allowedto goout ofIndia.
(b)With regard to foreign registered aircraft, while it may be
normally advisable for diplomatic reasons
to expedite the
hijacked aircraft's exit from the Indian territory and airspace.
Permission
may
be
granted
to
such
an
aircraft
when
unavoidably necessitated by the
circumstances
as
required
under Annex-17
to the Convention on International Civil
Aviation. In case of such landings, further action would be
taken in full consultation with the
concerned State.
5

Anti Hijacking Contingency

Chapter I
INTRODUCTION
(c)The hijackers would be engaged in negotiations for bringing an
ending to the incident without loss of life or capitulation to the
hijackers' demands, for obtaining relieffor passengers and crew
of the affected aircraft and even for practical reasons for getting
time to prepare for use of force. The demands of the hijackers
shall, however, not be conceded, especially if they have an
adverse impact on the national security.
(d)In case of unlawful seizure of an aircraft, if evidence of any
violence is reported or there
is
serious
apprehension
of
imminent violence on part
of those effecting the seizure,
adequate measures shall be taken to terminate the seizure,
including through use offorce.
1.8
The Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS), with Minister Civil
Aviation also as a Member, would be at the apex of the institutional
structure for crisis management.
Major policy and strategic decisions
will be taken by CCS on the advice of the Committee of Secretaries for
AircraftHijack (COSAH).The executiveresponsibility for hands on crisis
management would rest with the Central Committee chaired by DGCA,
and
the
Aerodrome
Committee
functioning
under
its
guidance/ supervision at the airport levelwhere the hijack aircraft lands.
Necessary authority and resources would be available to the Aerodrome
Committee for taking on-the-spot decisions and action based on their
assessment of the ground situation.
Airlineand airport operators shall
prepare
their
own Contingency Plans
in
line with
the
National
ContingencyPlan.

1.9
A detailed AviationSecurity (AVSEC)Manual on HandlingAircraft
Hijack Situation
will be prepared separately clearly specifying the
different scenarios possible in a hijack situation, as also the available
options and the modalities for handling these scenarios. The Manual will
also lay down clear Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)for different
agencies involved at the ground level for handling
such incidents and
effectiveon-line responses to deal with the situation successfully. This
would
be
in accordance
with the
International Civil Aviation
Organisation (ICAO)directions and would ensure that
action is taken
at different levels immediately on receipt of intimation about the hijack
without waiting for any higher levelofficersor decisions.

Chapter II
ON LINE RESPONSE
TO FIRST

2.5
For
rapid
and
systematic
collection and
dissemination
of
information regarding a hijacked aircraft, close co-operation is required
to be maintained between the security officials and the relevant Air
TrafficUnits in whose areas the unlawful seizure first becomes known.
The objective is to ensure that essential and desirable information is
collected and transmitted
in a step by step manner as the flight
progresses, to the appropriate security services and ATSUnits in each
State which may become involved so that
timely and appropriate
safeguarding action may be taken en-route and at the aircraft's known,
likelyor possible destination. The essential information includes:
"
(i)
The known or anticipated route offlight;
(ii)
The known or suspected destination and the estimated time
of arrival;
(iii)
Supplementary flight plan, data such as fuel endurance
(expressed in hours and minutes, if possible)and number of
persons on board, including crewand passengers;
(iv)
The composition of the flight crew and their knowledgeand
experienceofthe anticipated route;
(v)
The availability on board the aircraft of navigational charts
and associated documentation; and
(vi)
Flight time limitations of the flight crew taking into account
the number ofhours already flown.
10

2.6
The initial notification should be sent to all security services and
Air Traffic Services (ATS)Units within an area of probability to be
determined in each case, upon such circumstances as direction of flight,
range of aircraft, proximityto the borders ofother States or to other flight
information region and the need to provide advance warning, if possible,
of at least one or two hours, while avoiding unnecessary alerting on too
wide a scale. As a minimum, all the adjacent States along or those in the
proximityof the projected flightpath should be forewarned.
2.7
The information regarding possible destination,
identity and
objectives of the hijackers and developments in the situation will be
constantly intimated by FIC to the Central Committee Control Room,
COSAHControl Room and IB Control Room who in turn will apprise
Prime Minister, Minister (CivilAviation), Cabinet Secretary, Secretary
(CivilAviation),DGCA,COSCA,COSAH,Central Committeeetc. suitably.

by the concerned functionaries without waiting for any instructions or

NSG team
with necessary complement
of manpower
j
equipment will be airborne
within a maximum of
two
hours of
receipt of

can be
decided
by CCj CCS even after NSG team has taken off
from
Delhi Airport).

purpose
NSG would
immediately
contact
Cabinet
SecretariatjIAFjBSF
for
making an
aircraft ready for NSG movement. In case
Cabinet
Secretariat j IAFj BSF
aircraft is not available
for movement within maximum period of 2 (two) hours.,
NSG may requisition
any Indian registered aircraft at
DelhiAirport. (Standing Order
for this
purpose
would
be
issued
by
DGCA
to
all
concerned
Airlines
operators).

Chapter III
SITUATION MANAGEMENT
3.1
The following Committees will be the institutional structure for
managing the situation:-
(i)
Cabinet
Committee on
Security
including
Minister, Civil
Aviation(CCS)
(ii)** Committee of Secretaries on AircraftHijack (COSAH)
(ii)
Central Committee (CC)
(iii)
AerodromeCommittee (AC)
3.1.1 CCSjCOSAH would take major policy and strategic decisions,
while the responsibility for implementation of these decisions and
handling the situation on the ground would rest with CCj AC.
3.2
Cabinet Committee on Security
3.2.1 Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS)will be the apex body to
decide the policy and take decisions on strategic issues like response to
hijacker's demand involvingnational security, external affairs, political
implications, strategyj approach to negotiations, forcible termination of
the hijack etc. It willbe advised by COSAHfor this purpose. Minister of
Civil Aviation would also be
included
in
the CCS for management
ofaircraft hijack situations.
** The new nomenclature given to Crisis Management Group (CMG).

and

Govt.

of aircraft
hijack.
However, in case of prolonged crisis COSAHneed not necessarily
be
in continuous
session till the termination
of the hijack, and may
constitute a Sub Group instead,
which will be in session
on continuous
basis.
The composition of the Sub Group would be decided by COSAH
depending on the specific situation.
For example, the Sub Group could
be chaired by Foreign Secretary
in case an
Indian
registered
hijacked
aircraft
lands
at a foreign airport
and
by the
Home Secretary
in
case
armed
intervention
for termination of the
hijack
looks likely
(in case an Indian registered
hijacked aircraft
lands
at an Indian
civil airport).

represented
in
COSAH will have
broad roles as indicated
below:

Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
ChapterV
RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE AIR-CARRIERS
5.1
The Commander of a hijacked aircraft has very little choice except
to
obey
the
instructions
of the
hijackers.
In
consequence,
the
Commander
of the hijacked aircraft may not be in a position to fly the
aircraft in a manner
required by the Air Traffic Control Unit or in the
manner that the Commander himself desires.
5.2
The Commander
of the hijacked aircraft shall endeavour to notify
the appropriate
Air Traffic Service Units of this fact and any deviation
from the current flight plan necessitated
by the circumstances
in order to
enable ATS unit to give priority to the aircraft and to minimize conflict
with other traffic.
5.3
An aircraft
equipped
with Secondary
Surveillance
Radar
(SSR)
transponder
might operate the equipment as follows: -
(a) On Mode A, Code 7700; or
(b) On Mode A, Code 7500, to indicate specifically that it is
being
subjected to unlawful interference.
5.4
Wherever
the
Aircraft
has
any
secret
facility
to
communicate/cellular
phones/satellite
based phones, the crew may use
them to communicate
with the ground.
5.5
Airlines shall be responsible
to install
the equipment mentioned
in paras
5.4 in the
Indian
Registered
Aircraft for
the
purpose
of
communication,
details
of which
shall be
notified
by the
DGCA in
consultation
with COSCA.
31

everypossible effortto communicate the description ,number ofoffenders
and arms carried by them and their intentions to the ATC/Ground,and
all other relevant developments/information. Pre-determined codes may
also be used for this purpose.

Sky Marshals, if aboard the flight, would take action as per
Standard Operating Procedures(SOPs)laid downfor such situations.

".,
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter VIII
TERMINATION OF THE
HIJACK SITUATION
8.1
Policy of negotiation
8.1.1 Termination of
the hijack can
be through
negotiation or
through armed
intervention.
8.1.2 In the
first instance
, the hijackers would be engaged in
negotiations for bringing an ending to the incident without loss of lifeor
capitulation to the hijackers' demands, for obtaining relieffor passengers
and crew of the affectedaircraft and even for practical reasons for getting
time to prepare for use of force. The demands of the hijackers shall,
however,not be conceded, especiallyif they have an adverse impact on
the national security.
8.2
Objectives of negotiation
i)
Comfort
and safety of passengers
and
crew while
they are still in the aircraft
ii)
Their release unharmed
iii)
Releaseof Aircraft
iv)
Surrender of hijackers
37
SECRET
40:
SECRET
•
Government of India
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
......
, ,
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter VIII
TERMINATION OF THE
HIJACK SITUATION
8.3
Processof negotiation
8.3.1 The process of negotiation by local
negotiators
shall start as
soon as possible under the direction of the Aerodrome Committee.
8.3.2 A team of trained negotiators (the composition of which shall be
notified by Commissioner of Security CivilAviationfrom time to time)
with a complement of psychologists/psychiatrists shall be sent to the
Indian airport where the hijacked aircraft lands.
8.3.3 Their effort should be to ascertain the demands of the hijackers,
their mood, affiliationsetc. and in any case, the local negotiators should
continue dialogue till the arrival ofthe Central Team.
8.3.4 CC shall be kept constantly informedby ACabout the progress of
negotiations.
8.3.5 Central team of negotiators
shall be
properly briefed about
the
policy of
Government with
regard to the demands of the
hijackers. It is essential
to ensure as much delay as possible so as
to provide time for officials to evaluate the situation
and plan
the
best
possible counter
action, to create uncertainty
and stress
for
the
hijackers
to reduce
their
possibility
of their
making
surrender.
concentration
and enhance
the
mistakes
,and
talking
them
into

8.4
Armed intervention
8.4.1 In case negotiations fail and the CCS decides to terminate the
hijack through
armed intervention,
the responsibility for planning
the strategy
and taking
action with the use offorce shall be of the
Commander of the designated armed
force (NSGetc.) till the action is
over. The AC shall, however, continue to be in session and render all
assistance to the Commander. It shall also handle the situation arising
out ofthe armed intervention.
8.4.2 The decision of the CCS for armed intervention to terminate the
hijack
should be conveyedto the Commander ofthe
designated force
as wellas to their Operations Roomthrough the
Central Committee.
39

42:
SECRET
•
Government of India
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter IX
MEDIA MANAGEMENT
9.1.1 All efforts would
be made to ensure that the
media
acts as
facilitator and does not take the role of adversary. A pro-active media
management is a must. Acts of unlawful interference are covered by the
news media world-wide. Advanceunderstanding will have to be reached
with the news media for responsible reporting. They should be treated as
partners and not as adversaries in tackling the incidents of unlawful
interference to the civilaviation.
9.1.2
External Publicity (XP)Divisionof the Ministryof External Affairs
willalso be associated in media management.
9.1.3 Chairman
and
Members of
COSAH I CCI
AC
shall
not
interact
with
media as far as possible.
9.2
Media Management at Delhi
9.2.1 Principal Information Officer(PIO)shall
be responsible for media
management.
PIO as a member of COSAH, shall keep the COSAH
briefed about the appearance of information in the media about the
incident. PIO shall also counter any mis-information being propagated in
the media and correct other inaccuracies which the media may have in
projectingthe correct picture..
9.2.2 Norms for reporting the incidents shall be established by the Press
Information Bureau. In particular during the period of hijack, as far as
possible the news media may be requested
not to unduly publicize:

(c)Details of confidential measures
applied by the

9.3
Media management
at Aerodrome Committee level
9.3.1 Chairman
of the Aerodrome Committee at the affected airport
will

from

Information Department, who will brief

on behalf of the

speak to the media.
9.3.2 Access should not be
provided
to the media persons
to the
airside
of the terminal building, control rooms etc.

44:
SECRET
:I
Government
of India
BUREAU
OF CIVIL AVIATION
SECURITY
<
Anti Hijackin_g_Contingency
plan
Chapter
X
POSSIBLE
USE OF HIJACKED
AIRCRAFT
AS MISSILE
10.1 On 11thSeptember, 2001, civilian aircraft were hijacked in USA
and used as missiles/weapons to attack selected targets.
The objective
of the hijacks was evidentlynot to negotiate for meeting their demands,
as in many past hijacks but to destroy selected strategic targets. In view
of this experience, the contingency of suicide squad taking over an
aircraft for a similar purpose has also tobe envisagedand providedfor.
10.2 In the event of an Indian registered aircraft being hijacked, or a
hijacked foreignregistered aircraft flyingin the Indian air space, it would
be necessary to assess at the earliest whether the objectiveof the hijack
could be to attack strategic targets in India. If so, deterrent action would
need to be taken by Indian AirForcewithin moments to protect possible
strategic targets.
The Coordination Procedures (CP) and
Standard
Operating Procedures (SOPs)mutually developed by civil and defence
authorities
describe the likely situations which indicate that
an
aircraft may pose
a threat to strategic targets and as to when
the
activities of the aircraft/ pilot constitute air threat
to civil aviation. The
aboveCPand SOPmay be operationalisedas and when the need arises.

SECRET
-----------------------------------
45:
SECRET
•
Government of India
<
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter XI
INCIDENT REVIEW
11.1 Evaluation for continued effectivenessof Contingency Plan
shall
be a
regular
process. The Commissioner of Security (CivilAviation)
should depute an officeror a team of officers to conduct a preliminary
probe into the cause of the incident immediately.
11.2 In order to check the availability of Contingency Plan at each
airport and ensure that the plan is updated regularly, BCAS officers
during the course of their inspection of the airports will ensure that a
particular airport has its ContingencyPlan duly approved by BCAS,and
the same is updated from time to time. If any modification is called for
on the
basis of evaluation report, the same will be done by the
Chairman Aerodrome Committee at each airport on the directions to be
issued by the Commissionerof Security (CA),BCAS.
11.3 Due regard will be given to the need for periodic evaluation of
concepts and updating of plans,
the usefulness
of simulation
exercises and the capacity-building of the personnel responsible for
handling a hijack situation.
11.4 The system for monitoring and analyzing critical situations should
be appropriately established and positioned so as to be functional in
every respect for ensuring effectivecoverageand proper coordination
with the concerned decision making authorities.

46:
X
Government of India
,
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
Anti Hijacking Contingency plan
Chapter XI
INCIDENT REVIEW
11.5
After
termination
of the
Hijack situation,
the
COS(CA)will
constitute
a
committee
comprising
the
representative
from
BCAS/ASG/ NSG/ Airport
Operator/Airline
concerned
to
study
the
deficiencies in Aviation Security, if any, which might have led to the
unlawful interference and examine the whole issue in consultation with
DGCA,IB, MHAand MCA.
Based on the decision taken by the COS(CA),necessary action to
remedy the weakness in security system shall be taken so as to prevent
such recurrence in future.
Action taken in the matter will also be communicated to ICAO. In
order to ensure time bound action, the entire exercise shall be completed
within one
month
time
from the
date
of occurrence
of unlawful
interference.

SECRET
:I
Government of India
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY
,
Anti Hijacking Contingency
plan
Chapter XII
REPORTING
12.1 Alldocuments and materials relevant to the investigation of the act
of unlawful interference shall be kept in safe custody by respective
agencies and handed over to authorized agencies as per requirement.
12.2 The DGCAshall notify,by the most expeditious means, the State of
Registryof the aircraft and the State of Operator of the landing and shall
similarly transmit,
by
the
most
expeditious
means,
all
relevant
information relating to any unlawful interference in India to:
(a)
The two above mentioned States;
(b)
Each State whose citizens suffer fatalities or injuries;
(c)
Each State whose citizens are detained as hostages;
(d)
Each contracting State whose citizens are known to be
aboard the affectedaircraft; and
(e)
International CivilAviationOrganization
12.3 The affected air carrier shall fill in the prescribed proforma and
forward the same along with a written report of the pilot-in-command to
the appropriate authority i.e. BCASby the quickest possible means. The
Aerodrome Officer in-charge will likewise file report with the said
appropriate authority without delay along with the prescribed proforma.

REPORTING
Chapter
XII
Government
of India
BUREAU
OF CIVIL AVIATION
SECURITY
Anti Hijacking
Contingency
plan
12.4
Reports to ICAO
(a)
Preliminary Report- within thirty days of the occurrence of the
incident of unlawful interference to civil aviation, a report in
form prescribed in Appendix 10 of ICAOManual along with
relevant information, shall be submitted by COSCAto ICAO.
The format of preliminary report is givenas Annexure-IV.
(b)
Final Report - within sixty days of the occurrence of the
incident of unlawful interference to civil aviation, a report in
form prescribed in Appendix 10 of ICAOManual along with
relevant information, shall be submitted by COSCAto ICAOin
the same format givenas Annexure-IV.
12.5
A criminal case of unlawful interference to civilaviation under
relevant sections of law shall be got registered, normally by the
Airline concerned,
at
the
appropriate
police station
for
facilitating the investigation and prosecution of offenders.
